Just to clarify this 'golden rule' issue ...
 
 There is a very important distinction between Jesus' golden rule and that espoused by many other religions and cultures. This difference is well demonstrated in the 'Ethic of Reciprocity' Wikipedia link MrWrite was so kind to post for us all.
 
 Note some of the entries:
  * "Thou shalt not avenge, nor bear any grudge against the children of thy people, but thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself: I am the lord." - Torah Leviticus 19:18
 * "When an alien lives with you in your land, do not mistreat him. The alien living with you must be treated as one of your native-born. Love him as yourself, for you were aliens in Egypt. I am the lord your God." - Torah Leviticus 19:33-34
 * "This is the sum of duty; do naught unto others what you would not have them do unto you." - Mahabharata (5:15:17) (c. 500 B.C.)
 * "What you do not wish upon yourself, extend not to others." - Confucius (ca. 551 - 479 B.C.)
 * "What is hateful to you, do not to your fellow man." - Hillel (ca. 50 B.C. - A.D. 10)
 In most every case listed in the Wikipedia listings (particularly the pre-Jesus ones), the wording is "do not unto others". "Or do naught unto others." In other words, the message is: don't harm others because you wouldn't want it done to yourself. However Jesus' version goes a significant step further and changes it (in keeping with the gist of the whole Sermon on the Mount) by saying what you DO, "DO unto others as you'd have them DO unto you." The negative is changed to a positive, from not just the absence of doing bad to actually doing GOOD toward others. He clearly intentionally changed the golden rule (as it was already known) to not just be about 'not-hurting-people' to be about doing good. In other words, he up'ed the ante on the Golden Rule. This is consistent with the rest of the Sermon on the Mount, where he takes things like having to carry a cloak for a soldier to taking yet an extra mile over and above what is expected. The whole sermon is about up'ing the ante from the standards of society to a morality that goes beyond it. That's why it's ironic when people claim the Jesus' golden rule was no different than what was already in place in "virtually all major religions and cultures"; it's not the same. It's about going the extra mile, beyond  those very standards of culture.
 
 Sorry for the ... er, sermon, but I often hear the claim made that the golden rule appears in supposedly nearly every culture and religion, a claim no doubt made sometime because some can't stand the idea of the Bible possibly actually having a novel and superior uniqueness when it comes to a moral code. While it may be true that the "golden rule" has been around a lot longer than the Bible, that's not necessarily Jesus' form of the golden rule, which definitely goes farther.

Richardson failed to realize it wasn't a question about legislative action, but core convictions. Now we know where Richardson stands, huh?
 
 Last but certainly not least, we got ourselves a bit of Hillary Clinton. The front runner amongst gays and Democrats, Clinton seemed the most comfortable on stage, laughing and charming the pants and panties off the crowd. "I'm your girl," she laughed with Margaret Carlson. 
 
 Not surprisingly, Clinton had to defend her past stances on Don't Ask, Don't Tell, which her husband implemented, an issue she claims ranks as one of her top concerns.
 
 
 ...It's one of my highest priorities. I came out against don't ask/don't tell in 1999. It was a transitional action that was taken back at the beginning of my husband's administration because at the time, there was such a witch hunt going on. ...We have moved a long way on this and other issues.
 Clinton also believe the country has moved on the issue of marriage, which the Republicans once brandished as a weapon, but the majority of people seem to realize they were duped. As the tides change, Clinton says, she's sure we as Ameicans can get more rights.
 
 Clinton wrapped up by clarifying her post Peter Pace stumble. She initially took a neutral stance after Pace called gays "immoral," but rapidly shifted gears after gay activists criticized her wishy-washy answer. Clinton released a more harsh statement the next day, "I should have put it in a broader context." 
 
 The Senator garnered even more cheers after humanizing gay rights:
 
 
 And I want to be a president who can clearly say to the American people, you know, these are our friends, our children, our parents; these are people who we want to support as they live the best lives they can.
 The question remains, however: can we trust Hillary Clinton?
 
 We're not sure, but she did come off as one of the top contenders after last night, using her hag magic to work the crowd. While most of the candidates whored themselves a bit, we have to admit we're pleasantly surprised with how the forum's played out. No new issues were raised, but we got a good long look at the major issues facing gay communities - and heard where the candidates stand, or don't stand, on our civil rights.
Matthew S

I must say that if that is what Clinton and Obama said, then it simply does not hold water. In April the Democrats passed a bill requiring a timetable for the Iraq war. The President continuously threatened to veto the legislation. Both Clinton and Obama did not seem to see that fact as a reason not to vote for the bill. In face of such a fact, their statements can only be taken as hypocritical at best.
 
 I remain unconvinced that Clinton and Obama specifically can be taken as standing on principle. I perceive their statements last night as mere pandering.
 
 And as a matter of political punditry, I think it is a political mistake for the Democrats to stand so adamantly on this issue. Not only has gay marriage proved to be grossly unpopular with the general public, but it has also been shown to be an issue that energizes people against parties and candidates.
